title: Leo Varadkar supports Brexit extension to January 31
text:
Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar | Kenzo Tribouillard/AFP via Getty Images Leo Varadkar supports Brexit extension to January 31 UK can leave sooner if parliament ratifies the Brexit deal, Irish PM says.

Irish Prime Minister Leo Varadkar said he supports an extension of the Brexit deadline to January 31.

In a phone call with Donald Tusk this morning, Varadkar said he thinks the U.K. should be granted the extension it asked for, according to a spokesman for the Irish government.

"The Taoiseach confirmed his support for President Tusk’s proposal to grant the request for an extension which was sought by the UK," the spokesman said.

Boris Johnson wrote to the European Council president last week requesting that the Brexit deadline be delayed until the end of January. He was compelled to do so by the Benn Act, which was passed by British MPs last month.

U.K. lawmakers Tuesday night voted in favour of Johnson's Brexit deal, but refused to back his fast-tracked timetable to enshrine the deal into U.K. law before October 31.

Varadkar and Tusk “noted that it would still be possible for the U.K. to leave before January 31st, 2020 if the Withdrawal Agreement has been ratified in advance of that date,” the Irish government spokesman said.

The spokesman added that the Brexit extension is likely to be discussed further at the meeting of EU ambassadors in Brussels this evening. The meeting is scheduled for 5:30 p.m. Brussels time.
description: UK can leave sooner if parliament ratifies the Brexit deal, Irish PM says.
